reviews.review_msg: Very friendly and caring, always stays late to answer any and all extra questions regarding both the class and current events. As some others mentioned he can get sidetracked but that is purely due to his passion for the topics he explains. Provides helpful material every class, attend lectures and you'll do fine. Light on homework-lots of optional

Can't run a tutorial properly, which is an issue because there is a participation grade. He will speak for 3/4 of the time, leaving very little space for student participation. His lectures can often meander in an unproductive manner. That being said, he does care about his students, assigns great readings, and is very personable (and quite funny).

I am very big into history, but I don't like the way he teaches the class. If the exam answers aren't exactly the way he wants them, you will get a bad grade. During his lectures, you really have to pay attention because the lecture slides are very bland and don't show a lot of information. He just explains it all. Prepare to take a lot of notes!!!

I think Dr.Vinkovetsky is full of passion to teach and willing to help students for their papers. Such as after we submitted our proposal, he gave us feed back and talked with us individually and give us books that might help for our papers.

Not the class for you if you struggle to write tests as there's no term paper or assignment to balance the grade. My only critique is that you must attend every lecture to be up to date. I missed one week where the tutorial was cancelled (announced in class) and no announcement was sent via Canvas to let others know ;-; Ilya is a great prof!

Dr Vinkovetsky is one of the best professors in the history department at SFU. He is caring and deeply passionate about the topics covered in his course material. He brings forth an energy that is palpable and engaging that is hard not to share his enthusiasm. He is incredibly knowledgeable and provides excellent feedback.

If you like lectures, take this class. He is a quirky prof who provides a lot of material but you will learn a lot. Be ready to pay attention for two straight hours of lectures while taking notes! Good prof if you like to learn.

Amazing professor with a deep well of knowledge that he draws upon and shares with each and every student. Like any upper level class, you need to show up and put in the work, but if you do you will reap the rewards of knowledge and his expertise with the material.

While Ilya's lectures can sometimes go into random tangents, he is a super great guy! He is always so happy and he is extremely passionate about his subject. Although it is reading-intensive, it is a very basic 2nd year history course. I really enjoyed Ilya!

I am not a history major and took this class as an elective. The lectures are not bad but, you must attend as you will miss out on important information. Also, participating in tutorial makes a big difference in your mark. I think this is a good class to take as an elective as it is quite interesting. It spans from WWI to the fall of communism.
Engaging lectures can see/feel his interest in the subject during lectures. assigns a lot of readings, but if you take good enough notes you can just skim through the readings. Would take again.

Lectures can get a little off track at times, and he tends to talk excessively during tutorials, but his lectures and readings are quite important and fresh. If you can connect the themes of the readings to his lecture material, you'll do fine.

His lectures are pretty unorganized and all over the place. If you dont take good notes, youre doomed. Tutorial is all based on participation (20%). Would not recommend unless you want to teach yourselves all the content.

Prof.V is decent. His lectures can be a bit all over the place, but try your best to take good notes, because his tests mostly focus on lecture material instead of textbook (discala) material. You can actually do without the textbook entirely, just make sure that you read the 2 novels! They're important on the tests. Overall, solid, passionate guy

Do not take this class if you cannot learn on your own. He is very knowledgable, very disorganized and jumps around; going off on 30 minute tangents about nothing. Use the textbooks, participate in lectures, and prepare for random response papers. The material is interesting, but he is extremely difficult to follow. For papers, get to the point!

I think he doesn't really know about the course , and he is not fully prepared to lectures. He had never post anything on canvas, not even lecture slides &marks. Don't take it if you can't learn the course by yourself. Participation MATTERS.

Great prof, very knowledgable and interested in the subject. Definitely read the textbook because his lectures will jump all over the place and can be confusing and hard to follow. Vinkovetsky has a good sense of humour if you listen to him, and will tell funny history jokes. Beware of difficult marking on midterms. Tutorials are fun though!

Overall, I think he's a good prof. Sometimes he seems to get flustered over his words and stutters through sentences, but the meaning is never lost. I found the material very interesting. Di Scala textbook is easy to read but it's huge, and we read all of it. A lot of other reading too. The tests are straightforward, but my TA was a tough grader
Worst prof ive had. Can't lecture/understand him.

Vinkovetsky is a decent prof. Not the best lecturer, so lectures aren't particularly fluid or clear. Try your best to take notes though because the 224 textbook, Barricades & Borders, isn't great - too focused on minute details. Tests are mainly about broader themes w/ facts used as evidence. He likes to focus on the Ottoman Empire and Balkans.

Avoid. Go with tough, but awesome Dr. Garfinkel. Dr. Vinkovetsky's lectures are painfully slow, readings are unrelated andor a dog's breakfast, and marking is unclear and too low. Adding some evidence to this latter point, the 1st midterm saw a 64% average, the highest mark being 76%. 224 also focuses way too much on Eastern & Southern Europe.

He makes participation a massive component of the final grade and then crushes any opportunity for people to participate by answering his own questions. He doesn't know how to end his class . The amount of reading he assigns is ridiculous, and his feedback for assignments is lacking. He seems like a nice person, but avoid him as an instructor.

I am a first year and it was a really overwhelming course. There is a lot to read and are difficult readings. Though the TAs helped a lot with what the tests would look like. The tests are based on the readings and lectures. He bounces around a lot, talks fast, says he will send the slides but never does. There is a lot of topics covered too.

As many people have said he does jump around in lectures. It takes a while to get used to but focus on the general ideas and you'll be fine. The same goes for the readings. There were quite a few for the course but as long as you knew the arguments the authors made and tied that back in with what the lectures were you were fine.

Ilya's lectures are very tough to understand, not because of his his slight accent, but because he jumps around chronologically making it almost impossible to take helpful notes by hand. He also doesn't use powerpoint at all, so you have to write really fast to keep up with him, and his lectures are dull.

Disorganized lectures, couldn't follow along at all. He assigns a LOT of reading, all of it mandatory. 5-6 dense(ish) books, and that's what your tested on. But if you read the books closely and tie them in with what you can glean from the lectures, you're passing. Easy class, if you don't mind reading a lot and taking careful notes.

Vinkovetsky is a passionate and very nice prof, however his lectures have no visual aids such as powerpoints and his lectures tend to be confusing. Hard to take notes and follow along. Very helpful one on one!!!

FANTASTIC PROF. Very approachable - always responds to e-mails and will keep trying to teach until you understand. Exams are fair, everything on them has at least been mentioned in lecture. The lectures are consistent with the text and readings are interesting. One of the best profs at SFU from my experience!

Vinkovetsky is a great prof. Lectures were very interesting and his personal insight adds to the material. Knows everything about Soviet history. Many students taking this class as their first 300 level thought his grading was too hard...it wasn't.

The man's a champ.  Not at all what I expected, one of the better HIST profs I've had.  After the previous 2 terms of terrible profs, I had considered swearing off HIST courses for my minor, but Ilya definitely changed my mind.  Highly recommend.

This guy makes learning Russian history fun. Very passionate and enthusiastic about his subject. His personal stories reveal his genuine character. Laid-back teaching style. For paper topics, he gives students options to choose from. Showed a few films from Russian cinema. Cares about his students. One of the better history profs at SFU.
A very brilliant and energetic prof.  A bit scatterbrained maybe and his jokes seem to go over the head of most people in this entry level course..

Very insightful and enthusiastic professor. And he is approachable and great for conversation outside of class. The tests were challenging but not impossible. Lots on eastern Europe. Come prepared to lecture, and you will learn a lot.
Dr. Vinko is great. His seminar on Stalin was eye opening. Just a great class.

No organization and no visual aids in lecture. He stands infront of the class and speaks for an hour in a random manner. The lack of power point, or projector slides caused a severe lack of focus in his lecture! Hard to take notes
He uses humor a lot. Lectures are engaging. Lots of reading, but most of it is good.
Really wonderful teacher! One of the best classes I've taken at SFU.
This class makes you think. Great prof!

Great prof! The class itself is hard because of the overwhelming amount of reading and memorizing. But the prof is such an nice guy that if you show ur effort, he knows it and gives credits for it. I screwed my first test but excelled in the second one. He threw my first test mark away and only counted the second one. Work hard and u'll be fine!

When this man is on, he is on. Great ride of a class. Not just humour, humour with a purpose. Some of the lectures were truly insightful. He stresses what is important. Great class. Highly recommended.
Absolutely brilliant prof.  But you've got to do the reading to do well in the course!!  If you keep up, everything makes sense.

K - Ilya is very passionate, but is very difficult to understand with his studder. He also isn't clear in his lectures and marks very very difficult - as he looks for specific notes that he never mentioned in lecture.  Brought down many people's GPA
Fair marker, really tries hard to use humour in lectures which makes them really enjoyable. Highly recommend him!!!

Tries very hard and cares a lot.  Marking quite fair, lectures a bit of a mess sometimes, but he's trying.  Tutorials could be a lot better, but I have had worse.  Overall a good prof and a good guy.  I would take another class with him again.
Excellent, down-to-earth prof. The tests were challenging but fair. I love the options he gave for paper topics. He cares about the subject and sees students as people.
I really enjoyed his course. He made material that could be dry come to life. He has a great smile.

One of the best classes at SFU. Vinko is great. Awesome passion and enthusiasm. The lectures went in different directions, but never boring. At the end of the day gave me a new perspective on the twentieth century. Now I really understand now how USSR rose and fell. And he is a fair marker. Very approachable in office hours.

It can be too much readings at time. Not the best lecturer. He's a nice guy, tries to be as clear as possible. If you do all the readings, attend class and pay attention during lectures should be fine. Exams are straight foward.
An analytical mind. A thoughtful prof with a great sense of humor and style. Chooses readings well and listens to students.
Prof. Vinkovetsky is an excellent professor. He does give at times too much reading, but will help students through it with weekly questions and discussions.

*Really* nice guy, highly enthusiastic, very helpful and willing to make time for you. However - his lectures are barely linear, he stutters, then pauses and changes his line of thought very often, making note taking really tedious. His lectures often seem disorganized as a result. Lots of reading for the course, but it's not too hard.
He knows his stuff, and is totally enthusastic. He however, isn't the best lecturer in the world.

Great class! Prof is hilarous, and he knows his stuff. Gets a bit flustered at times but his exams are straight forward as long as you do the readings and attend lecture, and stay for the review sessions he does give hints!

Very nice professor, although his midterm was a bit hard he basically cancelled it out if you did better on the other assignments.  He is extremely enthusiastic and a great lecturer.  Perhaps the best professor I've ever had in history.
He is really nice, but his midterm exams were hard. He is very passionate about Russian history, but his lectures are very unclear. He doesn't present his material in a very organized manner.

Ilya is fabulous.  He appears a little unorganized but his pure love of the subject makes his class very interesting. And he is willing to help in anyway to help you learn!  Just fabulous in general. Definately a good prof to have teaching!
very unclear and hard demanding professor
very very nice man! lectures are unorganized and sooo much reading. Gives lots of notes in emails, tries to keep things fun, marks fairly hard
Very hard marker, lots of reading, very picky test questions. But Russian history is interesting anyway.
Poorly delivered lecture, confusing teaching style, too many text to read.
A nice guy but really unorganized. He is extremely vague about assignments and just seems to love counterfactuals. Save yourself the headaches and avoid

Very nice person and a professor.  Although he can be a bit vague, and his lectures having a few too many meaningless details, he still is a great professor, and tries extremely hard to help students.  Overall, I enjoyed his class quite a bit, and he made Russian history more interesting.

Worst prof ever! Very poor lecturer, changes topic in mid-sentence constantly, stammers, & is hard to follow. Gives tons of meaningless details.  Extremely hard marker and unfair. Purposely vague,gives false criteria to study for then changes criteria when marking.  Has a major Napolean complex.
He's an extremely enthusiastic and approachable prof. who conducts lively discussions. Not the easiest marker so be prepared to work for your grade
No Comments
